head.ce:title: New insight into the role of resistant starch in pig nutrition

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Feed & Food Science and Nutrition Institute, Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore, Piacenza, Italy

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Feed & Food Science and Nutrition Institute

ce:list-item.ce:para: Resistant starch is fraction of dietary starch that escapes digestion in upper intestinal tract.

Starchy ingredients entering pig diets contain from 50 up to 500
g/kg DM of resistant starch.
Resistant starch may impair energetic efficiency and feeding behavior of growing pigs.
Resistant starch may act as a potential prebiotic source favoring butyrate production.
Its fermentation could reduce the N emission from pig facilities.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In pig nutrition, the analysis of starch is merely focused on assessing total quantity. However, indications suggest that a certain fraction of starch, defined as resistant starch (RS), can escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract therefore passing into the large bowel where can act as fermentative substrate. Nutritionally RS, along with other non-starch polysaccharides and non-digestible oligosaccharides, is regarded as non-digestible carbohydrate. As for humans, the concept of RS has gained increasing attention also in pig nutrition. As a consequence, research to obtain a deeper knowledge on how different RS levels and types may affect energy metabolism, nutrient availability, pig performance and induce positive effects on pigs through fermentation has progressed recently. Therefore, this review comprises updated data on: (i) factors related to the RS content in feed; (ii) systemic effects of RS from various sources in pigs; (iii) aspects associated to the RS fermentation process and role of RS in the pig large intestine; (iv) possible implications of RS on the environmental load of pig facilities. Since the digestibility of starch is compromised in the early period after weaning, the present discussion will be mainly restricted to older animals (especially growing pigs).

ce:section.ce:para: Diets for pigs are based on starchy feeds as source of energy and raw cereal grains, along with legume grains and potato starch, constitute the main dietary starch source in pig rations ( Sun et al., 2006 ). Since starch represents a substantial component of diets, characterizing its properties and improving its utilization are important research focuses in pig nutrition. Overall, dietary starch is predominantly digested in the small intestine generating glucose as a final product for absorption ( Wiseman, 2006 ). Dietary starches from different sources are however digested and absorbed at different rates and to different extents depending on three major aspects, which are closely interrelated: (i) physical and chemical characteristics of starch, (ii) degree and type of processing prior to feeding and (iii) animal related factors ( Naficov and Beitz, 2007; Giuberti et al., 2014 ). Hence the rate, extent and site by which starch is degraded will have a range of physiological effects. Such variations can modulate the post-prandial metabolic response, thus having implications on nutrient absorption and pig performance ( Regmi et al., 2010; Menoyo et al., 2011; Drew et al., 2012 ). Considerable information concerning aforementioned factors is largely discussed in technical reviews ( Svihus et al., 2005; Bach Knudsen, 2011; Giuberti et al., 2014 ).

The RS fraction has a contradictory status in pig nutrition. In particular RS has been considered as a negative factor since this fraction may impair energetic efficiency and thus is not always well suited with whole body nutrient use and animal growth ( Sun et al., 2006; Rideout et al., 2008; Drew et al., 2012 ). However, there are ample evidences that RS and other sources of NDC act as potential prebiotic sources ( Fuentes-Zaragoza et al., 2011 ; Bach Knudsen et al., 2012 ), being a non-digestible dietary component that may affect the host beneficially by selectively stimulating the growth and/or the activity of specific bacteria in the large intestine ( Brown et al., 1997 ). In particular the RS fraction, having similar properties than dietary fibre ( Sajilata et al., 2006 ), can induce positive effects on pigs through fermentation, gut motility, stimulation of gut immunity, health of the host animal and parts of the nutrient management ( Williams et al., 2005; Regmi et al., 2011a; Zijlstra et al., 2012 ).

Considering the increasing attention of RS in pig nutrition, the present review will focus on: (i) factors related to RS content in feed; (ii) systemic effects of RS from various sources in pigs; (iii) aspects associated to the fermentation process of RS and role of RS sources in the pig large intestine; (iv) possible implications of RS on the environmental load of pig facilities. Since in diet formulation the level and the type of RS are not always reported or may be confounded by the analytical method used for quantification ( Brumovsky et al., 2009 ), this review will include only published works were the amount and source of RS have been well defined, in an effort to provide valuable information for readers. In addition, because the digestibility of starch is compromised in the early period after weaning ( Medel et al., 2004; Bach Knudsen et al., 2012 ), the present discussion will be restricted to older animals (especially growing pigs).

The term RS was coined by Englyst et al. (1982) where the presence of a fraction of starch resistant to digestion was discovered in the residue of cooked and cooled potatoes after amylase hydrolysis. Later, a formal definition of RS as “… the starch or products of starch degradation that escapes digestion in the small intestine of healthy individuals and may be completely or partially fermented in the large intestine acting as a prebiotic material… ” was established ( Asp, 1992 ). Then, in 2001, a revised definition of dietary fibre, which included RS under analogous carbohydrate, was introduced ( AACC, 2001 ).

To date, the in vitro method initially developed by Englyst et al. (1992) for human nutrition purpose has been widely used also for characterizing starchy ingredients or complex diets for pigs ( Giuberti et al., 2012a, 2013a; Prandini et al., 2014 ), even if criticisms mainly related to the extrapolation from in vitro to in vivo conditions have been arisen ( van Kempen et al., 2010 ). Accordingly, starch can be classified into three main categories, depending on their rate and extent of in vitro digestion. The first two categories include rapidly digestible starch (RDS; defined as the amount of starch digested in the first 20
min of an in vitro digestion) and slowly digestible starch (SDS; defined as starch that is digested after the RDS but in no longer than 120
min). Both RDS and SDS are completely digested in the small intestine ( Englyst et al., 1992 ). The third category defined as RS is referred to that fraction of starch that cannot be digested within 120
min and passes through the small intestine likely almost indigested. The latter is measured enzymatically as the difference between total starch (TS) and the sum of RDS and SDS fractions.

Chemically, RS is a linear molecule of α-1,4- D -glucan essentially derived from the amylose fraction with a relatively low molecular weight (1.2 ×
10 5
Da) ( Tharanathan, 2002 ). At present, based on the source of enzyme resistance and according to physical and chemical characteristics, the RS fraction has been further divided into five distinct subtypes: RS1 ( i.e., physically entrapped, inaccessible starch), RS2 ( i.e., native granular starch), RS3 ( i.e., retrograded starch), RS4 ( i.e., chemically modified starch) and RS5 ( i.e., amylose–lipid complexed starch) ( Evans, 2013 ).

The RS1 pertains to starch presents in whole and milled grains or seeds where starch granules are encapsulated within a protein matrix or cell wall material that prevent or retard the access of amylase enzymes ( Sajilata et al., 2006; Fuentes-Zaragoza et al., 2010 ). The RS2 describes native starch granules with inherent enzyme resistance due to conformation or structure of the starch granules themselves, as in raw potato starch and green bananas. Based on the amylose content, the RS2 can be further divided in two distinct classes defined as RS2 a for raw starch granules with a normal amylose content (within the range of 0–30%, on a TS basis) and RS2 b where amylose exceeds 30% ( Alsaffar, 2011 ). The latter type is unique as it retains its structure and resistance even during the processing ( Jiang and Jane, 2013 ). Both RS1 and RS2 represent residues of starch forms, which are digested very slowly and incompletely within the small intestine ( Sajilata et al., 2006 ). The RS3 refers to non-granular starch derived-materials generally formed during the retrogradation of amylose after gelatinization. In particular, heat treatments in an excess of water disrupt starch granules in a process known as gelatinization, which renders starch fully accessible to digestive enzymes ( Svihus et al., 2005 ). However, due to the intimate packing of amylose upon cooling (retrogradation), starch can form tightly packed structures of RS3 that are resistant to enzymes digestion ( Haralampu, 2000 ). Therefore, most moisture heat-processed feed may contain RS3 but differences in the conditions of processing and subsequent cooling can influence its relative content ( Parera et al., 2010; Alsaffar, 2011 ). The RS4 belongs to a various group of starch that have been chemically modified or re-polymerized and it is often used by food manufactures to alter the functional characteristic of starch ( Tharanathan, 2005 ). Their levels of resistance to digestion depend on the starch and the modification reaction used ( Sajilata et al., 2006; Miao et al., 2014 ). Considerable information concerning chemistry and functionality of RS4 can be obtained from a review of published data ( Fuentes-Zaragoza et al., 2010, 2011; Maningat and Seib, 2013 ) and will not be covered in this review. Lastly, a fifth type of RS ( i.e., RS5) has been recently developed via processing high-amylose maize starch with free fatty acids ( Hasjim et al., 2010a). The enzyme resistance of RS5 can be ascribed to the collapsed helical conformation of the starch–lipid complex, preventing amylose dispersion and interfering with the binding by enzyme for hydrolysis ( Morrison et al., 1993; Hasjim et al., 2013 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Resistant starch content in feed and enzymatic hydrolysis of starches
ce:section.ce:para:
Considering that RS1, RS2 and RS3 are the principal RS types usually found in appreciable amounts in starchy ingredients consumed by pigs ( Table 2
), only factors related to these specific RS types are presented. However, three additional considerations must be given. Firstly, most of the published data are based on in vitro procedures. Although these methods provide practical and reproducible approaches to study starch digestibility and are validated by quantitative comparison with the RS values obtained from in vivo experiments, they might oversimplify the digestion mechanism occurring in the small intestine ( Hasjim et al., 2010b ). Furthermore, the RS presence and its sub-type characterization, among and within different starchy feed and complex diets, result from the interplay of several physicochemical properties, that are no longer considered as alternatives but rather as complementary to each other, contributing to a multifactorial system. Lastly, interactions with other nutrients and animal-related factors ( i.e., enzyme capacity of the animal for starch degradation, transit time, rate of removal of digesta from the GIT and infectious diseases) can occur, potentially influencing the relationship between in vitro estimates of RS and ileal starch disappearance in pigs ( Black et al., 2009; Bach Knudsen, 2011; Gerrits et al., 2012 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Resistant starch type 1: Physically inaccessible starch
ce:section.ce:para:
In whole cereal grains and legume seeds, starch is encapsulated within robust and intact cell wall and protein structures that concur to form RS1. Accordingly, in cereal grains with hard endosperm, higher values of RS1 have been reported after in vitro digestion. For instance, Giuberti et al. (2013a) reported a higher RS content (from 202 to 381
g/kg DM) in maize kernels with greater proportion of vitreous endosperm (from 290 to 830
g/kg of endosperm, respectively). In maize, the vitreousness is visually identifiable as the proportion of the endosperm that exists as a glass like amorphous state ( Blasel et al., 2006 ) and as the amount of vitreous endosperm increases the accessibility of enzymes to substrate decreased, due to the compactness of the starch itself along with a denser protein matrix surrounding starch granules ( Giuberti et al., 2013a ). In particular, the presence of endosperm non-starch components ( i.e., lipids, proteins, minerals and cell wall components) entrapping starch granules in cereal grains and legume seeds can act as a physical barrier for amylase hydrolysis ( Svihus et al., 2005; Stevnebø et al., 2006
).

Extrinsic mechanisms applied to starch sources may also affect the RS1 formation and yield. Feed processing takes many forms, including but not limited to grinding, rolling, flaking, pelleting, steaming, expanding and extruding. Considerable evidence suggests that the effect of milling does not result solely from the disruption of surrounding cell wall and protein matrices, but damages to the starch granules including cracking, fracturing and internal changes to the granules occur, thus increasing the susceptibility of starch to be degraded ( Alsaffar, 2011 ). Different milling treatments can result in different particle size distributions, with large particles having a smaller surface area for enzymatic hydrolysis than smaller ones and are therefore higher in vitro RS content ( Mahasukhonthachat et al., 2010 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Resistant starch type 2: Native starch granules
ce:section.ce:para:
The general concept is based on the fact that intrinsic starch characteristics that have a restrictive effect on the hydrolysis process can simultaneously enhance the RS2 formation ( Wiseman, 2006; Giuberti et al., 2014 ). For native grains, several reports indicated that the RS2 content is positively related to the amylose content, amylose molecules being less accessible to enzymes as compared to amylopectin ( Hoover and Zhou, 2003; Hu et al., 2004 ). However, as reported by Themeier et al. (2005) , the amylose content may not fully explain differences in the presence of RS from different botanical origin ( Table 3
). Aspects related to the starch source ( Adeleye et al., 2014 ), granule morphologies ( i.e., size, shape and surface characteristics) ( Tester et al., 2006; Lee et al., 2011 ), degree of crystallinity ( Witt et al., 2012 ) and type of crystalline polymorphs ( i.e., A-, B- or C- types) ( Gallant et al., 1992 ) have been reported to influence the in vitro RS content. In addition, all these characteristics are species dependent and are also affected by growing conditions and post-harvested treatments ( Jane, 2006; Setiawan et al., 2010; Masoero et al., 2011 ). For instance, legumes and tubers have been shown to contain higher amounts of RS (mainly RS2) when compared to cereals ( Sandhu and Lim, 2008; Xu et al., 2013 ). It has been reported that the RS content broadly reflects the increasing size of starch granules with large granules (typically found in legumes and tubers) being characterized by a smaller surface area to volume ratio and hence a lower surface potentially exposed to hydrolysis by enzymes ( Ring et al., 1988; Tester et al., 2006; Giuberti et al., 2013b ). The different RS2 content of native starches from different sources can also be imputed to the type of arrangement of the crystal structure ( Blazek and Gilbert, 2010 ). In particular starch granules, exhibiting three types of crystalline domains, resist hydrolysis by digestive enzymes to different degree ( Tester et al., 2006; Blazek and Gilbert, 2010 ). Comparative studies reported that cereal and low-amylose starches are in general characterized by the A-type power diffraction pattern, which has an open structure rendering starches highly digestible ( Biliaderis, 1991 ). On the contrary, potato and high-amylose starches exhibit the B-type crystallinity, which is more resistant to digestion by pancreatic amylase because of a close-packed structure. The C-type pattern found in legume starch, which is intermediate between types A and B, can make pea starch slightly resistant to enzyme action ( Biliaderis, 1991 ).

Most raw starches are disrupted by heating in an excess of water. The process, commonly known as gelatinization, markedly increases the starch susceptibility for amylolytic degradation due to swelling of starch, loss of crystalline structure and thickening of the surrounding matrix ( Haralampu, 2000 ). Further information concerning the gelatinization process can be achieved elsewhere ( Tester and Morrison, 1990; Ratnayake and Jackson, 2008 ). Degrees of gelatinization may occur in feeds, as a function of temperature, treatment time, water addition and starch source ( Svihus et al., 2005 ). However, the structure of the amorphous material obtained after gelatinization of starch is not steady and, on cooling/drying of starch dispersed by gelatinization, a process of reassociation and recrystallization of the amylose and amylopectin chains occurs, known as retrogradation ( Karim et al., 2000 ). Starches with a high proportion of amylose are usually more susceptible to retrogradation after heat processing than normal or low-amylose ones ( Miles et al., 1985 ). In addition, amylose retrogradation was found to be a fairly fast event relative to amylopectin retrogradation, probably due to the essentially linear structure of amylose ( Lii et al., 2004 ). Retrograded amylose, due to its high resistance, was therefore identified as the main factor involved in RS3 formation ( Vasanthan and Bhatty, 1998 ). The amount of RS in processed feeds is mainly dependent on the degree of processing, which can result in an increase or decrease in the RS values from those found in native starches. As a consequence, under some circumstances, processing that involves heat and moisture in most cases destroys RS1 and RS2 but forms RS3 ( Faraj et al., 2004 ). Accordingly, Sun et al. (2006) reported that the proportion of RS3 was negligible in raw ingredients ( i.e., barley, peas and a mixture of potato starch and wheat bran), but markedly increased (by up 98%) after extrusion cooking at 145 °C. In addition, severe processing conditions (as during extrusion) have also been reported to increase formation of amylose–lipid complexes, and thus reduce starch digestibility ( Hasjim et al., 2013 ). However, results regarding the impact of extrusion on RS content of starches are conflicting ( Alsaffar, 2011 ). Several studies reported a decrease in the RS content after extrusion as a consequence of destruction of the granular structures ( Mahasukhonthachat et al., 2010 ). In contrast, increased values of RS after extrusion have also been reported. For instance, Chanvrier et al. (2007) observed a slight increase in enzyme RS for wheat and normal maize starch after extrusion process.

Overall, the different regional digestibility of starch (digestible vs. fermentable) can lead to different final products for absorption: (1) glucose, if the digestion occurs in the small intestine, or (2) volatile fatty acids (VFA), if starch is fermented in the large bowel ( Wiseman, 2006 ). Detailed information about the digestion and absorption of starch within the upper GIT of pigs can be obtained from reviews of published data ( Bach Knudsen et al., 2006; Dona et al., 2010; Shirazi-Beechey et al., 2011 ).

Even if it is assumed that total tract digestibility of starch is almost complete ( Bach Knudsen, 2011 ), at ileal level significant differences may occur thus proportionally yielding different amounts of RS entering pig large intestine ( Wiseman, 2006 ; Fig. 1
). Accordingly, Regmi et al. (2011a) recorded ileal starch flows ranging from 1.3 to 211
mg/g DM in pigs fed diets differing in the proportion of RS. There is general consensus that the consumption of dietary starches differing in RS content can modulate the post-prandial metabolic response, with implications on performance parameters, energy utilization, nutrient digestibility and quantitative or temporal release of hormones ( Regmi et al., 2010; Deng et al., 2010; Bach Knudsen, 2011 ). For instance, Regmi et al. (2011b) feeding to growing pigs four diets with a wide range of RS content (from about 30 to 850
g RS/kg TS) reported that the higher-RS diet (from high-amylose maize, RS2) decreased the net portal glucose and increased the net portal VFA flux postprandially.

The conversion of VFA absorbed after fermentation into body energy is generally assumed to be less efficient than that of glucose ( Bach Knudsen et al., 1993; Noblet et al., 1994 ), although can cover up to 15% of the maintenance energy requirements in growing pigs ( Bindelle et al., 2007 ). Bach Knudsen (2011) summarized that about 4% of energy comes from VFA in a maize-based diet, whereas higher values (from 7% to 44%) may be expected in pea and potato starch based diets, respectively. Accordingly, high RS diets (400
g/kg of TS from retrograded maize starch, RS3) have been associated to low digestible energy and metabolizable energy intake and energy retention in pigs ( Gerrits et al., 2012 ). As a consequence, the switch from digestible to fermentable starch may reduce the energetic efficiency ( Zijlstra et al., 2012 ) and may potentially impact nitrogen (N) retention ( Drew et al., 2012 ), fat metabolism ( Yin et al., 2011 ) and the net portal appearance of amino acids ( Li et al., 2008 ) in growing pigs with restricted access to feed. However, part of the lower energetic efficiency following RS intake may be compensated by a reduction in energy expenditure on physical activity, likely due to a decreased feeding motivation resulting from a gradual and prolonged supply of energy from fermentation ( Bolhuis et al., 2008; de Leeuw et al., 2008; Souza da Silva et al., 2012, 2014 ).

Growth performance, feed intake and feed efficiency decreased ( Li et al., 2007; Regmi et al., 2011a ) or were unaffected ( Nofrarías et al., 2007; Doti et al., 2014 ) by RS consumption, indicating that the both RS source and the amount consumed may play a role for such variations. For growing pigs, Pluske et al. (1998) reported that a daily intake of about 280
g of RS did not result in significant differences in average daily gain and live weight at slaughter with respect to other treatment groups, although animals took fewer days to reach the target weight. Accordingly, Doti et al. (2014) obtained similar growth performance traits ( i.e., average daily feed intake, average daily gain and final body weight) and carcass characteristics in gilts fed diets containing from 184 to 363
g/kg RS from cereal and legume grains.

Increasing levels of RS resulted in lower apparent ileal and total tract digestibilities of nutrients ( Sun et al., 2006; Gerrits et al., 2012; Cervantes-Pahm et al., 2014 ), mainly associated with changes in the rate of nutrient absorption or with increased endogenous secretions. In particular, Morel et al. (2005) calculated that as the RS in the diet increases by 1%, the total ileal starch digestibility may decrease by 0.64 percentage points. Accordingly, RS fermentation can reduce the apparent fecal digestibility of crude protein while increasing fecal N excretion at the expense of urinary N, due to an enhance excretion of microbial protein ( Sun et al., 2006 ). In addition, different RS sources at the same level of inclusion can differentially affect nutrient utilization. Following the consumption of three RS sources, Rideout et al. (2008) reported that pigs fed diets with an inclusion level of 100
g/kg of RS2 (from high amylose maize starch and from potato starch, respectively) were characterized by a lower apparent total tract digestibility of crude protein as compared to the control group, whereas no variation was reported for pigs fed a diet supplemented with 100
g/kg of RS3 (from retrograded maize starch). Martinez-Puig et al. (2003) reported that total tract apparent digestibilities of organic matter and starch were lower in pigs fed about 160
g/kg of RS2 through at least day 23 of the study, but values progressively increased up to day 38, at which no differences were recorded with respect to the control. Similar results were also confirmed in a long-term study ( i.e., 97 days; Martinez-Puig et al., 2007 ). Time-dependent changes in digestibility may reflect the need for an adaptation of the GIT to supplementary amounts of RS or, more likely, an age-related improvement in starch digestion in growing pigs, where, seemingly, fewer negative effects after RS ingestion have been reported. Using pigs weighting about 70
kg, Govers et al. (1997) reported that about 30–40% of RS (fed as high amylose maize starch; RS2) was recovered at the ileal level, whereas Heijnen and Beynen (1997) reported a much higher percentage of RS (in the range of 70%, from RS1 and RS3) for pigs weighting about 16
kg. These different quantities of RS entering the large intestine could have also implications in the expression of swine diarrhea. Accordingly, Pluske et al. (1996) reported that the clinical expression of swine dysentery after experimental infection may be reduced by feeding pigs diets low in fermentable substrate (non starch polysaccharides, RS and oligosaccharides), even if the precise contribution that these fractions may have played into the pathogenesis remains to be fully elucidated ( Pluske et al., 1998 ).

Consistent with human studies ( Robertson, 2012 ), a low postprandial glucose response was observed in pigs fed high RS diets, due to a reduced rate of starch digestion ( van Kempen et al., 2010; van der Meulen et al., 1997a ). In particular, Giuberti et al. (2012b) reported that maximal plasma glucose concentrations ranged from 15.0 to 64.2
mg/dl in growing pigs fed diets with a RS content of 72.5 and 4.5
g/100
g TS, respectively. In addition, feeding pigs diets based on maize or native pea starches, van der Meulen et al. (1997b) observed different rates of appearance of glucose in the portal vein, which led to significant differences of amino acids net portal flux. Similarly, low insulin secretion, as well as low apparent production of C-peptide (a more reliable marker for insulin secretion having a longer half-life than insulin itself) has been reported in pigs fed RS-rich diets ( Regmi et al., 2010 ). Taken together, these changes in the metabolic response can affect energy partitioning, feeding behavior and nutrient uptake by tissues and thereby pig productive performance ( van Kempen et al., 2007; Black et al., 2009; Doti et al., 2014 ). For instance, high insulin can lead to high fat deposition ( Newman et al., 2014 ) suggesting that the inclusion of high-RS sources in diets designed for pigs could reduce carcass fat accretion. However, at present, to what extent the RS intake is linked to carcass composition warrants further investigations. In addition, it must be pointed out that the release of insulin in not only related to net portal glucose concentrations, but also to VFA produced after RS and NDC fermentations, which may influence insulin release through the action of incretins such us glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) ( Baggio and Drucker, 2007; Nauck, 2009; Hooda et al., 2010 ), thus affecting the control of glucose homeostasis ( Burcelin et al., 2007; Regmi et al., 2011b ). Lastly, RS consumption has been also linked to total ghrelin secretion ( Robertson et al., 2005 ), an appetite stimulating hormone with possible roles in feed intake regulation, body weight gain and grown hormone release ( Carroll and Allee, 2009 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fermentability of resistant starch and impact in the large intestine
ce:section.ce:para: The effects of the presence of dietary material on the GIT physiology can be direct or indirect. Direct effects as modification of viscosity, water retention capacity and rate of passage of digesta are important throughout the entire GIT, with special relevance in the stomach and small intestine ( Anguita et al., 2007 ). On the contrary, indirect effects gain importance in the large intestine, where most of the fermentation process takes place. The concentration of various fermentation products, along with the presence of dietary and endogenous residues and with aged-related factors, may influence the gut environment, the microbiota and interact with colonic mucosa, leading to different response in the integrity and health of the digestive tract ( Brunsgaard, 1998; Mikkelsen et al., 2004 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Factors affecting fermentability of resistant starch
ce:section.ce:para: In general, pigs appeared to have a considerable capacity for fermentation of RS ( Wang et al., 2004; Sun et al., 2006; Jonathan et al., 2013 ), also at a pre-cecal level ( Bach Knudsen et al., 1991 ). Several studies have also shown that the extent of RS fermentation in pigs can increase over time ( Brown et al., 1997; Martinez-Puig et al., 2003 ) as a consequence of a progressive selection of particular bacteria populations, most likely starch-fermenting bacteria ( Topping and Clifton, 2001; Haenen et al., 2013 ).

In the large intestine, where RS is fermented by the colonic microbiota, the resulting main end products are gases ( i.e., H 2 , CO 2 and CH 4 ) and VFA (mainly acetate, propionate and butyrate) ( Bach Knudsen et al., 2012 ). Other fermentation products included lactate, succinate and bacterial cell biomass ( Montagne et al., 2003 ). It is generally accepted that the production of VFA can be considered to be favorable, while, for instance, production of ammonia, indicating a shift to protein fermentation, can have possible negative effects on health ( MacFarlane and MacFarlane, 1993 ). Several reports indicated that not only the total VFA production, but also the profile of each individual VFA depend on several factors, including chemical composition, physical form and availability of specific substrate to ferment ( MacFarlane and MacFarlane, 2003; Wang et al., 2004 ) as well as the microbial population during fermentation ( Williams et al., 2001, 2005 ). As substrates must be depolymerized by bacterial hydrolytic enzymes prior to fermentation, the rate of such depolymerization influenced the degree at which RS, and other sources of NDC, become available for bacteria ( MacFarlane and MacFarlane, 2003 ). In addition, the different degree of penetration of bacteria into starch granules, which is related to granule dimension and surface area, is essential for some bacterial strains and may also interfere with the enzymatic microbial activity ( Martinez-Puig et al., 2003 ). Correspondingly, evidence has arisen that not only the amount of RS entering the large bowel of pigs has importance ( Haenen et al., 2013 ), but also its composition and physical structure may affect total and individual VFA productions both in vitro and in vivo ( Martin et al., 1998; Regmi et al., 2011b; Jonathan et al., 2012 ). For instance, Martin et al. (2000) demonstrated that the in vivo fermentation of diets containing various types of RS ( i.e. , raw potato starch, RS2; high-amylose maize starch, RS2; retrograded high amylose maize starch, RS3) induced different patterns of appearance of VFA in the portal blood in pigs during a 14
h test period. Likewise, Giuberti et al. (2013b) , using a pig fecal inoculum and native starches as substrate, observed that in vitro quantitative and qualitative productions of VFA and related fermentation kinetics were influenced by the type of RS fermented. Similar results were also reported by Jha et al. (2011a) and by Torres et al. (2013) evaluating the concentration and composition of VFA after an in vitro fermentation of different cereal and legume grains, respectively.

There is a body of in vivo and in vitro experiments supporting the view that different RS sources and types can also affect the rate and site of fermentation in the large intestine ( Bird et al., 2007; Jha et al., 2011a ). As argued by Williams et al. (2005) , fermentation kinetics, combined with information about the transit time, can give an indication about where ingredients are fermented and could therefore be used to select RS sources eliciting fermentation in specific places of the GIT in pigs. Combinations of RS with various NDC sources are effective in moving the site of maximal carbohydrate breakdown further along the GIT of pigs ( Govers et al., 1999 ). The inclusion of slowly fermentable RS types in pig diets may therefore be desirable to provide further substrates generating VFA in the more distal parts of the colon ( Regmi et al., 2011a ), with possible reduction in high gut protein fermentation that produces known and harmful end products ( i.e., ammonia, amines, short-chain phenols and indoles) ( Jensen, 2001; Williams et al., 2005 ).

The VFA generated in the colon are physiological active in the large intestine and rapidly absorbed (from 0.95% to 0.99%) through the gut wall, from which they pass into the portal vein ( von Engelhardt et al., 1998 ). In general, VFA can exert specific physiological effects in pigs. For example, it has been reported that the presence of VFA will act as a trophic stimulus for the large bowel, will stimulate electrolyte and fluid transport and will lead to a drop in the pH, preventing overgrowth of potentially pathogenic bacteria ( Topping and Clifton, 2001; Williams et al., 2005; Metzler and Mosenthin, 2008 ). In terms of host metabolism, acetate reaches muscle tissues where it contributes to energy supply, while propionate is converted to glucose in the liver ( Williams et al., 2001). Butyrate can be easily metabolized by β-oxidation in the mitochondria and it provides from 0.60% to 0.70% of the total energy demand of colonocytes ( Mentschel and Claus, 2003 ). Both in vitro and in vivo experiments indicated that the fermentation of RS produces in general more butyrate than does fermentation of other sources of NDC ( Topping et al., 2003; Cervantes-Pahm et al., 2014 ). In addition to being an important respiratory fuel, butyrate has also been shown to have several cellular effects, since it can stimulate development, growth and renewal of intestinal cells ( Bach Knudsen et al., 2003 ) and can reduce in vivo epithelial cell apoptosis ( Mentschel and Claus, 2003 ), thus leading to decreased skatole formation and absorption ( Claus et al., 2003 ). Accordingly, long-term intake of RS as raw potato starch (source of RS2) reduced indices associated with damage to epithelial cells and increased the butyrate concentration in colon digesta of growing pigs, which might improve mucosal integrity ( Nofrarías et al., 2007 ).

In pigs, a large and diverse population of aerobic, facultative anaerobic and strictly anaerobic bacterial species support the physiological development and immunologic functions in the GIT ( Chowdhury et al., 2007; Willing and van Kessel, 2010 ). In a healthy adult pig, the GIT microbial community is an extremely complex system that comprises more than 400 species of bacteria ( Jensen, 2001 ), with difference in the number and composition within the various segments of the GIT ( Metzler and Mosenthin, 2008 ). The combination of digesta passage rate, amount and type of substrate to ferment and viscosity can generally contribute to nutrient availability and to the commensal bacterial colonization ( Bach Knudsen et al., 2012 ). Overall, the principle is that an appropriate ingredient in the diet would stimulate one or more beneficial bacterial species. Accordingly, switching from digestible to RS can provide greater available substrate for the commensal microbiota in the large intestine, RS being used by cecal and colonic microflora as fermentative substrate ( Suarez-Belloch et al., 2013 ). Hence, greater digesta mass may increase the diversity and population of the gut bacteria and several reports have indicated a potential interaction between RS and the microbial ecology of the pig ( Regmi et al., 2011b; Haenen et al., 2013 ). For instance, increased concentration of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus ssp. in the proximal colon, and that of Bifidobacterium spp. in pig feces, has been reported by Bird et al. (2007) and Regmi et al. (2011a) , respectively, as RS (from RS2 and RS3) increased. Similarly, Brown et al. (1997) reported the total fecal excretion of bifidobacteria was higher in pigs when RS2 from high amylose maize starch was fed. It is know that several strains of Bifidobacterium possess α-amylase and pullulanase activities required for specific use of starch in the large bowel ( Ryan et al., 2006 ). Recently, Lactobacillus sobrius/amylovorus has been described as major amylolytic species in the pig digestive microbiota ( Marti et al., 2010 ). Both Bifidobacteria and Lactobacillus genera are thought to be the principal health-giving bacteria in the gut of either humans or animals ( Wong et al., 2006 ).

Despite evidence exists that various source of RS have potential prebiotic effect (“…non-digestible food ingredients that beneficially affect the host by selectively stimulating the growth and/or activity of one or a limited number of bacteria in the colon…”) ( Gibson and Roberfroid, 1995 ) in pigs, the mechanism whereby RS can have on microbial diversity and colonization and on production and absorption of VFA remains to be fully elucidated. In the dynamic in vivo system, changes and variations in the VFA profile and in the microbial population in the pig large intestine are not only related to dietary composition, but also by the host, the microbiota and their interaction ( Williams et al., 2005; Jha et al., 2011a ). For instance, it must be pointed out that the RS-induced changes in the gut microbiota are strictly related to the initial composition of the host microbiota and that different types of RS, and even different crystalline polymorphism of the same type of RS, can selectively promote certain bacterial groups in different locations of the intestine ( Haenen et al., 2013; Suarez-Belloch et al., 2013 ).

While improving animal performance, swine nutritionists are also engaged on strategies toward a reduction of N emission from pig facilities. Increased intestinal carbohydrate fermentation has been reported to potentially shift the excretion of N from urine to feces ( van der Meulen et al., 1997a; Zervas and Zijlstra, 2002; Bindelle et al., 2009 ) as more ammonia N is taken up by bacteria in the large intestine ( Mosenthin et al., 1992 ) and less reaches the portal-drained viscera to be converted in urea in the liver before being excreted in urine. Since N emission from manure is mainly from urea N content in urine, RS fermentation at intestinal level, along with other sources of NDC, could potentially reduce ammonia N losses from manure. In addition, the increased proportion of VFA, due to enhanced fermentation, contributed to lowering the pH in the colon and to feces acidification, thereby reducing the ammonia emissions during manure storage and handlings ( Nahm, 2003 ). Such effects are counterpart of dietary modulation effect of RS which could benefit the animal also in relation to the amount of insoluble non-starch polysaccharides in the diet that might shift the place of RS fermentation from ceacum and proximal colon further distally in the GIT ( Govers et al., 1999 ). Among the places where RS might be fermented in the large intestine, the distal part of the large bowel seems to yield more microbial protein in the feces and shift of N from urine to feces ( Martinez-Puig et al., 2003 ). This is important in consideration of the progressive increase along the large bowel of the activity of proteolytic bacteria yielding branched-chain VFA from deamination of amino acids ( Martinez-Puig et al., 2003 ). Thus, the inclusion of RS, along with other sources of NDC, might be an effective approach to modulate the gut environment and, at the same time, could be a promising tool for reducing the environmental load of pig facilities ( Bindelle et al., 2008 ). Despite indications are emerging ( Bindelle et al., 2007; Jha et al., 2011b ) many NDC sources have not been investigated in this perspective yet, and there is still a lack of proper in vivo studies. Finally, fecal N excretion is not only related to the amount and availability of fermentable carbohydrates, but it is a function of indigestible protein content as well ( Jha and Leterme, 2012 ). As a consequence, further studies are currently warranted, along with a combined economical and environmental evaluation, while programming for N excretion and management for pigs.

Progress toward correlating properties of starch to digestibility and thus to the RS content is evident. Literature pointed out that different amounts and types of RS may interact with the digestive process along the entire GIT, inducing several changes in the kinetics of digestion and fermentation and (or) in the modulation of the microbial community. In addition, potential may exist in the use of particular types of RS in reducing the environment footprint of swine breeding. This will give the opportunity to adapt breeding programs for the selection of particular feed for specific pig requirements. However, currently available feed tables on the chemical composition and nutritional values hardly take into consideration the RS level and its fractions. Further studies are therefore warranted in order to identify appropriate sources and suitable amounts of RS that can promote intestinal health and positive environmental issues while preserving animal performance and the economic sustainability of the entire pig production system.
The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
